How the new iPhone 15 models differ from one another (and the iPhone 14) 4 Comments Drawer Tech / Apple How the new iPhone 15 models differ from one another (and the iPhone 14) The iPhone 15 brings better cameras and USB-C, but is Apple’s new lineup all that different from the last one? The iPhone 15 brings better cameras and USB-C, but is Apple’s new lineup all that different from the last one? by Sheena Vasani Sep 13, 2023, 7:49 PM GMT+1 Link Facebook Threads 4 Comments / 4 New Every version of the iPhone 15 includes a brighter display and Apple’s Dynamic Island feature. Photo by Nilay Patel / The Verge Sheena Vasani writes about tech news, reviews gadgets, and helps readers save money by highlighting deals and product recommendations for The Verge . To the surprise of no one, Apple announced the new iPhone 15 during its Wonderlust event on Tuesday, introducing it alongside the new Apple Watch Series 9 and an updated pair of AirPods Pro that come with a USB-C charging case. That means, as of today, Apple’s iPhone lineup consists of the iPhone 15 , 15 Plus, 15 Pro , and 15 Pro Max, as well as the last-gen iPhone 14 , iPhone 13, and the third-gen iPhone SE . The iPhone 15 lineup won’t be available until September 22nd, but you can preorder the phones on September 15th, starting at $799. Related How to preorder Apple’s upcoming iPhone 15 models A first look at the new iPhone 15 with USB-C and a big camera upgrade iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max hands-on Every phone in the new iPhone 15 lineup comes with a USB-C port and does away with the notch in favor of Apple’s Dynamic Island feature. Meanwhile, the more premium phones — specifically the iPhone 15 Pro and 15 Pro Max — come equipped with the new A17 Pro chip, an Action Button , and 10Gbps transfer speeds. This is all exciting stuff, but do these new improvements justify the price? To help you decide, we’ve put together a spec-by-spec breakdown of how the entry-level iPhone 14 models stack up against the entire iPhone 15 lineup ahead of our full reviews later this month. Price and size Before we dive into the nitty-gritty details, we should probably address one of the more significant differences between the various models: the price. The 6.1-inch iPhone 14 has dropped to $699, while the iPhone 15 starts at $799. The iPhone 14 Plus and iPhone 15 Plus go for $799 and $899, respectively, both of which come with a larger 6.7-inch display. Related Here’s how Apple’s new iPhone 15 models compare to some of the best Android phones The 6.1-inch iPhone 15 Pro, meanwhile, starts at $999, while the 6.7-inch iPhone 15 Pro Max starts at $1,199. Along with more capabilities (which we’ll dive into shortly), the Pro models offer a 1TB storage option, which the entry-level iPhone 14 and 15 models lack. None of the iPhone 15 models sport a notch. Instead, they support the Dynamic Island. Photo by Dan Seifert / The Verge Display and design Now let’s talk about the display. This year, Apple swapped out the notch found on the lower-end iPhone 14 and iPhone 14 Plus for the Dynamic Island. Once reserved only for the premium iPhone 14 models, the feature essentially acts as a moveable pill-shaped cutout, one that displays real-time notifications, alerts, and activities. Related Dynamic Island isn’t such an exciting destination after all — and that’s okay Apple’s new USB-C iPhone cables and dongles are predictably expensive Speaking of changes to the display, every phone in the iPhone 15 lineup features a brighter screen than the iPhone 14, with a peak brightness of 2,000 nits. Theoretically, this means the display should be easier to view when you’re outside, though we’ll let you know how that pans out once we’ve tested it. Here, we compare the last-gen iPhone 14 to the new iPhone 15 models to help you decide which phone is right for you.","datePublished":"2023-09-13T18:49:41+00:00","dateModified":"2023-09-13T18:49:41+00:00","url":"https://www.theverge.com/23860594/iphone-15-vs-14-plus-pro-max-comparison-specs-price-apple","mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.theverge.com/23860594/iphone-15-vs-14-plus-pro-max-comparison-specs-price-apple","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","name":"The Verge","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2025/01/verge-placeholder_f212b3.png?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0,0.13712291199202,100,99.725754176016","width":"1200","height":"628"}},"articleSection":"Apple","keywords":["Apple","Apple Event","iPhone","Tech","Versus"],"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Sheena Vasani","url":"https://www.theverge.com/authors/sheena-vasani"}],"isAccessibleForFree":false,"image":[{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916310/DSC_1099.jpeg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0,10.732984293194,100,78.534031413613","height":"2915","width":"5568"},{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916310/DSC_1099.jpeg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0,0,100,100","height":"3712","width":"5568"},{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916310/DSC_1099.jpeg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=16.666666666667,0,66.666666666667,100","height":"3712","width":"3711"}],"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xpath":["/html/head/title","/html/head/meta[@name='description']/@content"]},"articleBody":"To the surprise of no one, Apple announced the new iPhone 15 during its Wonderlust event on Tuesday, introducing it alongside the new Apple Watch Series 9 and an updated pair of AirPods Pro that come with a USB-C charging case. That means, as of today, Apple’s iPhone lineup consists of the iPhone 15, 15 Plus, 15 Pro, and 15 Pro Max, as well as the last-gen iPhone 14, iPhone 13, and the third-gen iPhone SE. The iPhone 15 lineup won’t be available until September 22nd, but you can preorder the phones on September 15th, starting at $799.
Every phone in the new iPhone 15 lineup comes with a USB-C port and does away with the notch in favor of Apple’s Dynamic Island feature. Meanwhile, the more premium phones — specifically the iPhone 15 Pro and 15 Pro Max — come equipped with the new A17 Pro chip, an Action Button, and 10Gbps transfer speeds.
This is all exciting stuff, but do these new improvements justify the price? To help you decide, we’ve put together a spec-by-spec breakdown of how the entry-level iPhone 14 models stack up against the entire iPhone 15 lineup ahead of our full reviews later this month.
[Video: iPhone 15 Pro Max: titanium, Action Button, and USB-C]
Price and size
Before we dive into the nitty-gritty details, we should probably address one of the more significant differences between the various models: the price. The 6.1-inch iPhone 14 has dropped to $699, while the iPhone 15 starts at $799. The iPhone 14 Plus and iPhone 15 Plus go for $799 and $899, respectively, both of which come with a larger 6.7-inch display.
The 6.1-inch iPhone 15 Pro, meanwhile, starts at $999, while the 6.7-inch iPhone 15 Pro Max starts at $1,199. Along with more capabilities (which we’ll dive into shortly), the Pro models offer a 1TB storage option, which the entry-level iPhone 14 and 15 models lack.
[Image: None of the iPhone 15 models sport a notch. Instead, they support the Dynamic Island. https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916168/DSCF3256.JPG?quality=90&strip=all]
Display and design
Now let’s talk about the display. This year, Apple swapped out the notch found on the lower-end iPhone 14 and iPhone 14 Plus for the Dynamic Island. Once reserved only for the premium iPhone 14 models, the feature essentially acts as a moveable pill-shaped cutout, one that displays real-time notifications, alerts, and activities.
Speaking of changes to the display, every phone in the iPhone 15 lineup features a brighter screen than the iPhone 14, with a peak brightness of 2,000 nits. Theoretically, this means the display should be easier to view when you’re outside, though we’ll let you know how that pans out once we’ve tested it. In addition to the Dynamic Island, the iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max also feature an always-on display, which is something the entry-level iPhone 14 and 15 models lack.
There are also some notable design differences to be aware of. Only the iPhone 15 and Pro Max feature a titanium body, for example, which should make the smartphones both stronger and lighter. They’re also the only Apple phones to feature the Action Button, which essentially takes the place of the ringer button and can be customized to create shortcuts, launch the camera, and carry out a range of other tasks.
[Image: The iPhone 15 Plus, like the other phones in Apple’s 2023 lineup, finally features a USB-C port. https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916142/DSCF3231.JPG?quality=90&strip=all]
Charging and battery life
Unsurprisingly, USB-C is perhaps one of the more notable updates this year. Each phone in the iPhone 15 lineup now features a USB-C port on the bottom instead of Apple’s proprietary Lightning connector, which the iPhone 14 lineup is still stuck with. The long-rumored switch should allow for faster charging and higher data transfer rates, too, and is particularly true of the 15 Pro, which Apple says is the first phone to offer 10Gbps transfer speeds. That means it should be significantly faster at transferring large files, including photos and videos.
In terms of battery life, both the iPhone 14 and iPhone 15 max out at 20 hours, while the iPhone 15 Pro Max should last the longest at up to 29 hours. Both Plus models offer up to 26 hours of video playback, but strangely, the iPhone 15 Pro maxes out at 23 hours.
[Image: Apple introduced larger 48MP main camera sensors in the iPhone 14 Pro Max last year, which are now available on every iPhone 15 model. https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24020041/226270_iPHONE_14_PHO_akrales_0724.jpg?quality=90&strip=all]
Cameras
When it comes to cameras, the entry-level iPhone 14 and iPhone 15 models share a dual-camera system that includes a 12-megapixel ultrawide camera. This year, however, the iPhone 15 and 15 Plus offer an improved 48-megapixel main shooter — more specifically, the same high-resolution main camera found in the Pro models. In contrast, the iPhone 14 offers a lower-resolution 12-megapixel main shooter. The new iPhone 15 lineup also brings some updates to both night mode and Portrait mode, the latter of which will now automatically go into effect when you’re taking photos of people or animals.
All of the entry-level models lack the triple-camera array found in the premium iPhone 15 models, which includes an additional 12-megapixel telephoto lens. You can also now change the main camera lens in the Pro models and shoot at multiple focal lengths: 24mm, 28mm, and 35mm. The iPhone 15 Pro Max has a new 5x tetraprism zoom lens with a 120mm focal length, too, which is the most Apple has ever offered and longer than the 3X 77mm focal length on the iPhone 15 Pro.
There are also notable improvements when it comes to video recording. All of the phones feature a cinematic mode that can record 4K resolution at 30fps and 4K at 24fps. However, the 15 Pro models will also be able to capture “spatial video” later this year, which are essentially 3D videos that can be viewed with Apple’s forthcoming Vision Pro headset. They will also allow you to shoot 4K60 ProRes video and, thanks to their support for USB-C, let you record video to external storage devices.
[Image: You’ll be able to capture spatial videos later this year on the iPhone 15 Pro models, which you can then watch on the Apple Vision Pro. https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916539/apple_spatial_video_vision_pro.png?quality=90&strip=all]
Processing power
In terms of performance, the iPhone 14 and iPhone 14 Plus use the two-year-old A15 Bionic chipset, which we found fast enough in our testing. However, it’s likely less snappy than the A16 found in the entry-level iPhone 15 models and probably more noticeably so when compared to the premium phones. The iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max run on the new A17 Pro chip, after all, which Apple claims to be some of the fastest chips currently available.
Combined with an updated GPU, Apple says the new smartphones are particularly well-suited for demanding tasks, including gaming. The iPhone 15 Pro seems to handle games well enough, at least in our brief time playing with it, but we’ll have to test it more to know for sure.
Speaking of chips, the iPhone 15 comes with a second-gen ultra wideband chip like the new Apple Watch Series 9. The updated component enables more precise tracking when using Apple’s Find My network, thus making it easier to find friends and loved ones who are also using an iPhone 15. It also should improve connectivity to other devices with the same chip that are further away.
[Image: The new StandBy mode in iOS 17 turns your phone into something like a smart display when it’s charging. https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24703759/wwdc_2023_243.jpg?quality=90&strip=all]
Software
Finally, when it comes to software, the iPhone 15 lineup ships with iOS 17. So far, that seems like a minor update that brings fun little features like Live Voicemail, a new Journal app, and StandBy mode. The latter turns your screen into something akin to a smart display, one that remains visible while your phone is charging in landscape mode. It should be noted, however, that you’ll also be able to download iOS 17 on the iPhone 14 and 15 Plus when it launches on September 18th, so you’ll be able to play with these features no matter which phone you buy.
By the numbers
There are other smaller differences to be aware of. All of the phones also support 5G, but only the 15 Pro models feature Wi-Fi 6E support. That makes them more futureproof and allows for faster wireless performance. The premium phones also come with a Thread radio built in, which can be used to control Thread-enabled smart home devices.
That’s just a brief overview of some of the main differences between the iPhone 15 and iPhone 14 lineup, though. You can dig into the more granular differences in the chart below, where we’ve rounded up all the relevant specs.
[Table: iPhone 14 models versus iPhone 15]

#onetrust-banner-sdk button, #onetrust-pc-sdk button, #ot-sdk-cookie-policy button {
  border-radius: 2px;
}

/* Button font */
#onetrust-pc-sdk button,
#onetrust-banner-sdk.ot-iab-2 #onetrust-button-group button {
font-family: var(--font-polysans-mono);
font-weight: 400;
}

/* Banner content width */
#onetrust-banner-sdk .ot-sdk-container, #onetrust-pc-sdk .ot-sdk-container, #ot-sdk-cookie-policy .ot-sdk-container {
  max-width: 1137px;
}

/* Divider border color */

@media only screen and (min-width: 1024px) {
#onetrust-banner-sdk.ot-iab-2 #onetrust-policy-text, #onetrust-banner-sdk.ot-iab-2 :not(.ot-dpd-desc)>.ot-b-addl-desc {
border-right-color: rgba(0,0,0,0.20);
}
}

/* Wider buttons */

  #onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-accept-btn-handler, #onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-reject-all-handler, #onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-pc-btn-handler {
   min-width: 145px; 
  /* font-weight:normal;
  font-size: .75em;
text-transform:uppercase; */
  }

/* Tablet button */

@media only screen and (min-width: 897px) and (max-width: 1023px) {
#onetrust-banner-sdk.vertical-align-content #onetrust-button-group-parent {
    left: auto;
    right: 0;
    min-width: 155px;  /* button min-width + 10 */
}
}

/* ALL SITES */

/* Mobile paragraph margin */

@media only screen and (min-width: 426px) and (max-width: 549px) {
#onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-policy {
    margin-left: 0;
    margin-right: 0;
}
}

/* Underline, non-bold links */

#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk a[href], #onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk a[href] font, #onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk .ot-link-btn {
font-weight:normal;
text-decoration: underline;
}

/* Tablet button positioning */

@media only screen and (min-width: 1024px) {
#onetrust-banner-sdk.ot-iab-2 #onetrust-button-group-parent {
    left: auto;
    right: 0;
    width: auto;
}
}

@media only screen and (min-width: 769px) {
#onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-button-group {
    margin-right: auto;
}
}




/* Minimize empty header */
@media only screen and (max-width: 1023px) {
#onetrust-banner-sdk .ot-dpd-title {
font-size: 0.5em;
}
}


/* Title under main header */
#onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-policy-title, 
#onetrust-banner-sdk .ot-dpd-title {
margin-bottom: 0.25em; }

/* Don't stack buttons on tablet */
@media only screen and (min-width: 426px) and (max-width: 896px) {
  #onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-button-group button,
  #onetrust-banner-sdk.ot-iab-2 #onetrust-button-group button {
    display: inline-block;
  }
}

/* Smaller top padding on mobile */
@media only screen and (max-width: 425px) {
  #onetrust-banner-sdk #onetrust-policy {
      margin-top: 1.25em;
  }

class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">To the surprise of no one, Apple announced the <a href="/2023/9/12/23862837/iphone-15-event-apple-watch-ultra-airpods-usb-c">new iPhone 15</a> during its Wonderlust event on Tuesday, introducing it alongside the new <a href="/2023/9/12/23860234/apple-watch-series-9-price-release-date-features">Apple Watch Series 9</a> and <a href="/2023/9/12/23860305/airpods-pro-usb-c-cases-apple-announced">an updated pair of AirPods Pro</a> that come with a USB-C charging case. That means, as of today, Apple’s iPhone lineup consists of the <a href="/2023/9/12/23859779/iphone-15-plus-usb-c-price-release-date-apple">iPhone 15</a>, 15 Plus, <a href="/2023/9/12/23859756/iphone-15-pro-max-price-features-release-date-apple">15 Pro</a>, and 15 Pro Max, as well as the last-gen <a href="/23352282/iphone-14-review-apple">iPhone 14</a>, iPhone 13, and the <a href="/22975531/apple-iphone-se-2022-review-price-specs-screen-battery">third-gen iPhone SE</a>. The iPhone 15 lineup won’t be available until September 22nd, but you can preorder the phones on September 15th, starting at $799.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _1o279nj1 _1o279nj0 duet--article--article-body-component"><div class="duet--article--related _1ymtmqpj _1m6r73h0"><h3 class="_1m6r73h1">Related</h3><ul class="_1m6r73h4"><li class="_1m6r73h7 _1m6r73h6"><a href="https://www.theverge.com/23859935/iphone-15-plus-pro-max-preorder-buy-price-release-date-apple" class="_1m6r73h9">How to preorder Apple’s upcoming iPhone 15 models</a></li><li class="_1m6r73h7 _1m6r73h6"><a href="https://www.theverge.com/23870387/iphone-15-plus-hands-on-pictures-video-price" class="_1m6r73h9">A first look at the new iPhone 15 with USB-C and a big camera upgrade</a></li><li class="_1m6r73h7 _1m6r73h6"><a href="https://www.theverge.com/23859793/iphone-15-pro-max-hands-on-pictures-video-apple" class="_1m6r73h9">iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max hands-on</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">Every phone in the new iPhone 15 lineup comes with a USB-C port and does away with the notch in favor of Apple’s Dynamic Island feature. Meanwhile, the more premium phones — specifically the iPhone 15 Pro and 15 Pro Max — come equipped with the new A17 Pro chip, an <a href="/2023/9/12/23870156/iphone-15-pro-action-button-ring-silence">Action Button</a>, and 10Gbps transfer speeds.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">This is all exciting stuff, but do these new improvements justify the price? To help you decide, we’ve put together a spec-by-spec breakdown of how the entry-level iPhone 14 models stack up against the entire iPhone 15 lineup ahead of our full reviews later this month.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _1o279nj1 _1o279nj0 duet--article--article-body-component"><div class="_2ezt6b0"><div class="duet--media--video-embed _1ymtmqpj"><div class="_1ozko3v0"><div style="background-image:url(https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2025/01/iphone-15-pro-max-titanium-action-button-and-usb-c.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=7.8125,0,84.375,100)" class="duet--media--content-warning ucljxw0"><div class="_1ozko3v1"><iframe allowfullscreen="" class="_1ozko3v2" title="iPhone 15 Pro Max: titanium, Action Button, and USB-C" allow="autoplay" src="https://volume.vox-cdn.com/embed/1137bad8f?autoplay=false&loop=true&placement=article&player_type=youtube&tracking=article:middle" loading="lazy" data-analytics-placement="article:middle" data-volume-placement="article" data-analytics-action="volume:view:article:middle" data-volume-uuid="1137bad8f" id="video-1137bad8f"></iframe></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><div id="sprjx3" class="_1m1ib701 _1m1ib700 duet--article--standard-heading _1xwtict1"><h2 class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup">Price and size</h2></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">Before we dive into the nitty-gritty details, we should probably address one of the more significant differences between the various models: the price. The 6.1-inch iPhone 14 has dropped to $699, while the iPhone 15 starts at $799. The iPhone 14 Plus and iPhone 15 Plus go for $799 and $899, respectively, both of which come with a larger 6.7-inch display.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _1o279nj1 _1o279nj0 duet--article--article-body-component"><div class="duet--article--related _1ymtmqpj _1m6r73h0"><h3 class="_1m6r73h3 _1m6r73h1">Related</h3><ul class="_1m6r73h5"><li class="_1m6r73h8 _1m6r73h6"><a href="https://www.theverge.com/23860505/apple-iphone-15-pro-android-specs-comparison-versus-samsung-google" class="_1m6r73h9">Here’s how Apple’s new iPhone 15 models compare to some of the best Android phones</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">The 6.1-inch iPhone 15 Pro, meanwhile, starts at $999, while the 6.7-inch iPhone 15 Pro Max starts at $1,199. Along with more capabilities (which we’ll dive into shortly), the Pro models offer a 1TB storage option, which the entry-level iPhone 14 and 15 models lack.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _1o279nj3 _1o279nj0 duet--article--article-body-component"><div style="position:relative"><div class="_1ymtmqpj"><div class=""><div style="background-image:none" class="duet--media--content-warning ucljxw0"><div class="duet--article--image-gallery-image kqz8fh0" style="aspect-ratio:1.5" id="dmcyOmltYWdlOjUxNzAz"><a class="kqz8fh1" href="https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916168/DSCF3256.JPG?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0,0,100,100" data-pswp-height="2944" data-pswp-width="4416" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer"><img alt="None of the iPhone 15 models sport a notch. https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916168/DSCF3256.JPG?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C0%2C100%2C100&w=1920 1920w, https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916168/DSCF3256.JPG?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C0%2C100%2C100&w=2048 2048w, https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916168/DSCF3256.JPG?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C0%2C100%2C100&w=2400 2400w" src="https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916168/DSCF3256.JPG?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C0%2C100%2C100&w=2400"></a></div></div></div><div class="duet--media--caption qama0i0"><figcaption class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup _1xwtict2 qama0i2"><em>None of the iPhone 15 models sport a notch. Instead, they support the Dynamic Island.</em></figcaption> <cite class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup _1xwtict2 qama0i1">Photo by Dan Seifert / The Verge</cite></div></div></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><div id="vhPPlU" class="_1m1ib701 _1m1ib700 duet--article--standard-heading _1xwtict1"><h2 class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup">Display and design</h2></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">Now let’s talk about the display. This year, Apple swapped out the notch found on the lower-end iPhone 14 and iPhone 14 Plus for the Dynamic Island. Once reserved only for the premium iPhone 14 models, the feature essentially acts as a moveable pill-shaped cutout, one that displays real-time notifications, alerts, and activities.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _1o279nj1 _1o279nj0 duet--article--article-body-component"><div class="duet--article--related _1ymtmqpj _1m6r73h0"><h3 class="_1m6r73h1">Related</h3><ul class="_1m6r73h4"><li class="_1m6r73h7 _1m6r73h6"><a href="https://www.theverge.com/23864716/iphone-15-dynamic-island-live-activities-wonderlust" class="_1m6r73h9">Dynamic Island isn’t such an exciting destination after all — and that’s okay</a></li><li class="_1m6r73h7 _1m6r73h6"><a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/9/12/23870441/apple-usb-c-cables-lightning-dongle-price" class="_1m6r73h9">Apple’s new USB-C iPhone cables and dongles are predictably expensive</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">Speaking of changes to the display, every phone in the iPhone 15 lineup features a brighter screen than the iPhone 14, with a peak brightness of 2,000 nits. Theoretically, this means the display should be easier to view when you’re outside, though we’ll let you know how that pans out once we’ve tested it. In addition to the Dynamic Island, the iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max also feature an always-on display, which is something the entry-level iPhone 14 and 15 models lack.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">There are also some notable design differences to be aware of. Only the iPhone 15 and Pro Max feature a titanium body, for example, which should make the smartphones both stronger and lighter. They’re also the only Apple phones to feature the <a href="/2023/9/12/23870156/iphone-15-pro-action-button-ring-silence">Action Button</a>, which essentially takes the place of the ringer button and can be customized to create shortcuts, launch the camera, and carry out a range of other tasks.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _1o279nj3 _1o279nj0 class="duet--media--caption qama0i0"><figcaption class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup _1xwtict2 qama0i2"><em>The iPhone 15 Plus, like the other phones in Apple’s 2023 lineup, finally features a USB-C port.</em></figcaption> <cite class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup _1xwtict2 qama0i1">Photo by Dan Seifert / The Verge</cite></div></div></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><div id="rGTR69" class="_1m1ib701 _1m1ib700 duet--article--standard-heading _1xwtict1"><h2 class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup">Charging and battery life</h2></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">Unsurprisingly, USB-C is perhaps one of the more notable updates this year. Each phone in the iPhone 15 lineup now features a USB-C port on the bottom instead of Apple’s proprietary Lightning connector, which the iPhone 14 lineup is still stuck with. The long-rumored switch should allow for faster charging and higher data transfer rates, too, and is particularly true of the 15 Pro, which Apple says is the first phone to offer 10Gbps transfer speeds. That means it should be significantly faster at transferring large files, including photos and videos.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">In terms of battery life, both the iPhone 14 and iPhone 15 max out at 20 hours, while the iPhone 15 Pro Max should last the longest at up to 29 hours. Both Plus models offer up to 26 hours of video playback, but strangely, the iPhone 15 Pro maxes out at 23 hours.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _1o279nj3 _1o279nj0 class="duet--media--caption qama0i0"><figcaption class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup _1xwtict2 qama0i2"><em>Apple introduced larger 48MP main camera sensors in the iPhone 14 Pro Max last year, which are now available on every iPhone 15 model.</em></figcaption> <cite class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup _1xwtict2 qama0i1">Photo by Amelia Holowaty Krales / The Verge</cite></div></div></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><div id="GftcJK" class="_1m1ib701 _1m1ib700 duet--article--standard-heading _1xwtict1"><h2 class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup">Cameras</h2></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">When it comes to cameras, the entry-level iPhone 14 and iPhone 15 models share a dual-camera system that includes a 12-megapixel ultrawide camera. This year, however, the iPhone 15 and 15 Plus offer an improved 48-megapixel main shooter — more specifically, the same high-resolution main camera found in the Pro models. In contrast, the iPhone 14 offers a lower-resolution 12-megapixel main shooter. The new iPhone 15 lineup also brings some updates to both night mode and Portrait mode, the latter of which will now automatically go into effect when you’re taking photos of people or animals.</p></div><div data-concert-ads-name="desktop_article_body" class="m-ad m-ad__dynamic_ad_unit duet--ad-container--default m-ad__desktop_article_body"><div id="div-gpt-ad-desktop_article_body" class="dynamic-js-slot dfp_ad--held-area" style="min-width: 600px; height: 366px;"></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">All of the entry-level models lack the triple-camera array found in the premium iPhone 15 models, which includes an additional 12-megapixel telephoto lens. You can also now change the main camera lens in the Pro models and shoot at multiple focal lengths: 24mm, 28mm, and 35mm. The iPhone 15 Pro Max has a new 5x tetraprism zoom lens with a 120mm focal length, too, which is the most Apple has ever offered and longer than the 3X 77mm focal length on the iPhone 15 Pro.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _1o279nj1 _1o279nj0 duet--article--article-body-component"><div class="duet--article--related _1ymtmqpj _1m6r73h0"><h3 class="_1m6r73h3 _1m6r73h1">Related</h3><ul class="_1m6r73h5"><li class="_1m6r73h8 _1m6r73h6"><a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/5/23750003/apple-vision-pro-hands-on-the-best-headset-demo-ever" class="_1m6r73h9">I wore the Apple Vision Pro. It’s the best headset demo ever.</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">There are also notable improvements when it comes to video recording. All of the phones feature a cinematic mode that can record 4K resolution at 30fps and 4K at 24fps. However, the 15 Pro models will also be able to capture “spatial video” later this year, which are essentially 3D videos that can be viewed with <a href="/2023/9/12/23860400/apple-vision-pro-mixed-reality-headset-release-date">Apple’s forthcoming Vision Pro headset</a>. They will also allow you to shoot 4K60 ProRes video and, thanks to their support for USB-C, let you record video to external storage devices.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement models, which you can then watch on the Apple Vision Pro.</em></figcaption> <cite class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup _1xwtict2 qama0i1">Image: Apple</cite></div></div></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><div id="PshXks" class="_1m1ib701 _1m1ib700 duet--article--standard-heading _1xwtict1"><h2 class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup">Processing power</h2></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">In terms of performance, the iPhone 14 and iPhone 14 Plus use the two-year-old A15 Bionic chipset, which we found fast enough in our testing. However, it’s likely less snappy than the A16 found in the entry-level iPhone 15 models and probably more noticeably so when compared to the premium phones. The iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max run on the new A17 Pro chip, after all, which Apple claims to be some of the fastest chips currently available.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">Combined with an updated GPU, Apple says the new smartphones are particularly well-suited for demanding tasks, including gaming. The iPhone 15 Pro seems to handle games well enough, at least in our <a href="/23859793/iphone-15-pro-max-hands-on-pictures-video-apple">brief time playing with it</a>, but we’ll have to test it more to know for sure.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">Speaking of chips, the iPhone 15 comes with a second-gen ultra wideband chip like the new <a href="/23862174/apple-watch-series-9-ultra-2-preorder-buy-price-release-date">Apple Watch Series 9</a>. The updated component enables more precise tracking when using Apple’s Find My network, thus making it easier to find friends and loved ones who are also using an iPhone 15. It also should improve connectivity to other devices with the same chip that are further away.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _1o279nj3 _1o279nj0 display when it’s charging.</em></figcaption> <cite class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup _1xwtict2 qama0i1">Image: Apple</cite></div></div></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><div id="0vEoh1" class="_1m1ib701 _1m1ib700 duet--article--standard-heading _1xwtict1"><h2 class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup">Software</h2></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">Finally, when it comes to software, the iPhone 15 lineup ships with iOS 17. So far, that seems like a minor update that brings fun little features like <a href="/2023/6/5/23738813/apple-ios-17-features-specs-updates-wwdc-2023">Live Voicemail</a>, a new <a href="/23750998/apple-ios-17-journal-app-ai">Journal app</a>, and <a href="/2023/6/5/23739121/apple-ios17-standby-apple-home-smart-display-wwdc-2023">StandBy mode</a>. The latter turns your screen into something akin to a smart display, one that remains visible while your phone is charging in landscape mode. It should be noted, however, that you’ll also be able to download iOS 17 on the iPhone 14 and 15 Plus <a href="/2023/9/12/23863224/ios-17-release-date-apple-iphone-15-announcement">when it launches on September 18th</a>, so you’ll be able to play with these features no matter which phone you buy.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _1o279nj1 _1o279nj0 duet--article--article-body-component"><div class="duet--article--related _1ymtmqpj _1m6r73h0"><h3 class="_1m6r73h3 _1m6r73h1">Related</h3><ul class="_1m6r73h5"><li class="_1m6r73h8 _1m6r73h6"><a href="https://www.theverge.com/23798104/apple-standby-mode-iphone-ios-17-clock-widgets-photos-customize-how-to" class="_1m6r73h9">How to use the new StandBy mode on iOS 17</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><div id="YkEg0Q" class="_1m1ib701 _1m1ib700 duet--article--standard-heading _1xwtict1"><h2 class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup">By the numbers</h2></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">There are other smaller differences to be aware of. All of the phones also support 5G, but only the 15 Pro models feature Wi-Fi 6E support. That makes them more futureproof and allows for faster wireless performance. The premium phones also <a href="/2023/9/12/23870522/iphone-15-pro-max-thread-smartphones">come with a Thread radio built in</a>, which can be used to control Thread-enabled smart home devices.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1ymtmqpi _17nnmdy1 _17nnmdy0 _1xwtict1">That’s just a brief overview of some of the main differences between the iPhone 15 and iPhone 14 lineup, though. You can dig into the more granular differences in the chart below, where we’ve rounded up all the relevant specs.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _1o279nj3 _1o279nj0   --zephr-footer-background-color: white;
  --zephr-footer-close-color: black;

#zephr-zone-footer {
  background-color: var(--zephr-footer-background-color);
}

#zephr-footer-close {
  color: var(--zephr-footer-close-color);
}

    .zephr-zone-footer {
        display: none;
        width: 100%;
        bottom: 0;
        position: fixed;
        left: 50%;
        transform: translateX(-50%);
        z-index: 1000;
    }

    .zephr-overlay {
        position: fixed;
        display: none;
        width: 100%;
        height: 100%;
        inset: 0;
        background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5);
        z-index: 2;
    }

    .zephr-zone-popup::backdrop {
        background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5);
    }

    .zephr-zone-popup + .backdrop {
        background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5);
    }

    .zephr-zone-popup {
        padding: 0;
    }

    .zephr-zone-close {
        margin: auto;
        padding:10px;
        position:absolute;
        right: 0;
        cursor: pointer;
        color: white;
        background-color: transparent;
        border: none;
        top:0;
    }

    .zephr-svg-close{
        height: 15px;
    }

    .zephr-zone-close:hover {
        background-color: transparent;
    }

    /*polyfill css*/
    dialog {
        position: absolute;
        left: 0; right: 0;
        width: -moz-fit-content;
        width: -webkit-fit-content;
        width: fit-content;
        height: -moz-fit-content;
        height: -webkit-fit-content;
        height: fit-content;
        margin: auto;
        border: solid;
        padding: 1em;
        background: white;
        color: black;
        display: block;
    }

    dialog:not([open]) {
        display: none;
    }

    dialog + .backdrop {
        position: fixed;
        top: 0; right: 0; bottom: 0; left: 0;
        background: rgba(0,0,0,0.1);
    }

    ._dialog_overlay {
        position: fixed;
        top: 0; right: 0; bottom: 0; left: 0;
    }

<script type="text/javascript">
(function() {
    const zoneCloseButtons = document.getElementsByClassName("zephr-zone-close");
    const zonePopup = document.getElementById('zephr-zone-popup');
    const zoneFooter = document.getElementById('zephr-zone-footer');
    const overlay = document.getElementById('zephr-overlay');
    let datalayer;
    let scrollPosition = 0;
    let isScrollLocked = false;


    function moveToBody(e) {
      if(!e){
        return;
      }
      // Only move if not already in body
      if (e.parentNode !== document.body) {
        try {
         document.body.appendChild(e)
        } catch (err) {
         console.log(err);
        }
      }
    }

    moveToBody(zonePopup);
    moveToBody(zoneFooter);
    moveToBody(overlay);

    window.Zephr = window.Zephr || {};
    function lockScroll() {
        scrollPosition = window.scrollY;
        document.body.style.overflow = 'hidden';
        document.body.style.position = 'fixed';
        document.body.style.top = `-${scrollPosition}px`;
        document.body.style.width = '100%';
        isScrollLocked = true;
    }

    function unlockScroll() {
        if (!isScrollLocked) {
            return;
        }
        document.body.style.removeProperty('overflow');
        document.body.style.removeProperty('position');
        document.body.style.removeProperty('top');
        document.body.style.removeProperty('width');
        window.scrollTo({
          left: window.scrollX,
          top: scrollPosition,
          behavior: 'instant'
        });
        isScrollLocked = false;
    }

    function onCloseZone(e, button){
        e.stopImmediatePropagation();
        const id = button.id.split('-')[1];
        const event =  new CustomEvent(`zephr.${id}.closed`,{
            bubbles:true,
            cancelable:true
        });
        document.dispatchEvent(event);
        if(id === "popup"){
            zonePopup.close();
        } else{
            button.parentNode.style.display = 'none';
        }
        unlockScroll();

        if(overlay){
          overlay.style.display = 'none';
        }
        
        if (datalayer && window[datalayer]) {
            window[datalayer].push({
                'event': `zephr.${id}.closed`
            });
        }
    }

    for (let i = 0; i < zoneCloseButtons.length; i++) {
        let button = zoneCloseButtons[i];
        // Only add event listener if not already attached
        if (!button.dataset.zephrListenerAttached) {
            button.addEventListener('click', e => onCloseZone(e, button));
            button.dataset.zephrListenerAttached = 'true';
        }
    }

    function onOpenModal(){
        zonePopup.showModal();
        lockScroll();
        datalayer = zonePopup.dataset.datalayer;
        window[`${datalayer}`] = window[`${datalayer}`] || [];
        window[`${datalayer}`].push({
            'event': 'zephr.popup.shown'
        })
    }
    function onCloseModal(){
        const closeButton = document.getElementById('zephr-popup-close');
        if(closeButton){
            closeButton.dispatchEvent(new Event('click'))
        }
    }

    function showOnScrollDown(onOpenZone){
        if (window.innerHeight >= document.body.clientHeight) {
            onOpenZone();
        } else {
            // Only add scroll listener if not already attached
            if (!window.Zephr.scrollHandlerAttached) {
                function scrollHandler(ev) {
                    if ((window.innerHeight + Math.round(window.scrollY)) >= document.body.offsetHeight/2) {
                        onOpenZone();
                        window.removeEventListener('scroll', scrollHandler);
                        window.Zephr.scrollHandlerAttached = false;
                    }
                }
                window.addEventListener('scroll', scrollHandler);
                window.Zephr.scrollHandlerAttached = true;
            }
        }
    }
    function onOpenAfter(zone, onOpenZone) {
        const openAfter = zone.dataset.openAfter;
        if(openAfter === 'scrollDown'){
            if(document.readyState === 'complete'){
                showOnScrollDown(onOpenZone)
            } else {
                // Only add load listener if not already attached
                if (!window.Zephr.loadHandlerAttached) {
                    function loadHandler() {
                        showOnScrollDown(onOpenZone);
                        window.removeEventListener('load', loadHandler);
                        window.Zephr.loadHandlerAttached = false;
                    }
                    window.addEventListener('load', loadHandler);
                    window.Zephr.loadHandlerAttached = true;
                }
            }
        } else if(openAfter == 0){
            onOpenZone()
        } else if(openAfter > -1){
            setTimeout(onOpenZone,openAfter * 1000)
        }
    }

    if(zonePopup){
        window.Zephr.openModal = onOpenModal;
        window.Zephr.closeModal = onCloseModal;

        // Only add event listeners if not already attached
        if (!zonePopup.dataset.zephrListenersAttached) {
            zonePopup.addEventListener('click', e => {
              if (e.target.tagName === 'DIALOG'){
                onCloseModal();
              }
            });
            zonePopup.addEventListener('cancel',e=>{
                e.preventDefault();
                onCloseModal();
            });
            zonePopup.dataset.zephrListenersAttached = 'true';
        }
        onOpenAfter(zonePopup,onOpenModal);
    }

    function onOpenFooter(){
        zoneFooter.style.display = 'block';
        const scrollable = zoneFooter.dataset.scrollable;
        if(scrollable === 'false'){
            lockScroll();
            overlay.style.display = 'block';
        }
        datalayer = zoneFooter.dataset.datalayer;
        window[`${datalayer}`] = window[`${datalayer}`] || [];
        window[`${datalayer}`].push({
            'event': 'zephr.footer.shown'
        })
    }

    if(zoneFooter){
        window.Zephr.openFooter = onOpenFooter;
        onOpenAfter(zoneFooter,onOpenFooter);
    }
})();

the surprise of no one, Apple announced the <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/9/12/23862837/iphone-15-event-apple-watch-ultra-airpods-usb-c">new iPhone 15</a> during its Wonderlust event on Tuesday, introducing it alongside the new <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/9/12/23860234/apple-watch-series-9-price-release-date-features">Apple Watch Series 9</a> and <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/9/12/23860305/airpods-pro-usb-c-cases-apple-announced">an updated pair of AirPods Pro</a> that come with a USB-C charging case. That means, as of today, Apple’s iPhone lineup consists of the <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/9/12/23859779/iphone-15-plus-usb-c-price-release-date-apple">iPhone 15</a>, 15 Plus, <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/9/12/23859756/iphone-15-pro-max-price-features-release-date-apple">15 Pro</a>, and 15 Pro Max, as well as the last-gen <a href="https://www.theverge.com/23352282/iphone-14-review-apple">iPhone 14</a>, iPhone 13, and the <a href="https://www.theverge.com/22975531/apple-iphone-se-2022-review-price-specs-screen-battery">third-gen iPhone SE</a>. The iPhone 15 lineup won’t be available until September 22nd, but you can preorder the phones on September 15th, starting at $799."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"RelatedPostsBlockType","__typename":"RelatedPostsBlockType","links":[{"url":"https://www.theverge.com/23859935/iphone-15-plus-pro-max-preorder-buy-price-release-date-apple","title":"How to preorder Apple’s upcoming iPhone 15 models"},{"url":"https://www.theverge.com/23870387/iphone-15-plus-hands-on-pictures-video-price","title":"A first look at the new iPhone 15 with USB-C and a big camera upgrade"},{"url":"https://www.theverge.com/23859793/iphone-15-pro-max-hands-on-pictures-video-apple","title":"iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max hands-on"}],"placement":"default"},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"Every phone in the new iPhone 15 lineup comes with a USB-C port and does away with the notch in favor of Apple’s Dynamic Island feature. Meanwhile, the more premium phones — specifically the iPhone 15 Pro and 15 Pro Max — come equipped with the new A17 Pro chip, an <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/9/12/23870156/iphone-15-pro-action-button-ring-silence">Action Button</a>, and 10Gbps transfer speeds."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"This is all exciting stuff, but do these new improvements justify the price? To help you decide, we’ve put together a spec-by-spec breakdown of how the entry-level iPhone 14 models stack up against the entire iPhone 15 lineup ahead of our full reviews later this month."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"VideoBlockType","__typename":"VideoBlockType","autoplay":false,"caption":{"html":"","plaintext":""},"isSensitive":false,"placement":"default","video":{"title":"iPhone 15 Pro Max: titanium, Action Button, and USB-C","volumeUuid":"1137bad8f","player":"youtube","poster":{"thumbnails":{"horizontal":{"url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2025/01/iphone-15-pro-max-titanium-action-button-and-usb-c.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=7.8125,0,84.375,100"}},"id":"dmcyOmltYWdlOjU1MjI1Mw=="},"id":"dmcyOnZvbHVtZVZpZGVvOjExMzM5OA==","publishedAt":"2023-09-12T17:00:00+00:00"}},{"__isBlockType":"CoreHeadingBlockType","__typename":"CoreHeadingBlockType","contents":{"html":"Price and size"},"headingId":"sprjx3","level":2,"placement":"default"},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"Before we dive into the nitty-gritty details, we should probably address one of the more significant differences between the various models: the price. The 6.1-inch iPhone 14 has dropped to $699, while the iPhone 15 starts at $799. The iPhone 14 Plus and iPhone 15 Plus go for $799 and $899, respectively, both of which come with a larger 6.7-inch display."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"RelatedPostsBlockType","__typename":"RelatedPostsBlockType","links":[{"url":"https://www.theverge.com/23860505/apple-iphone-15-pro-android-specs-comparison-versus-samsung-google","title":"Here’s how Apple’s new iPhone 15 models compare to some of the best Android phones"}],"placement":"default"},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"The 6.1-inch iPhone 15 Pro, meanwhile, starts at $999, while the 6.7-inch iPhone 15 Pro Max starts at $1,199. Along with more capabilities (which we’ll dive into shortly), the Pro models offer a 1TB storage option, which the entry-level iPhone 14 and 15 models lack."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"CoreImageBlockType","__typename":"CoreImageBlockType","alt":"","hideCredit":false,"placement":"wide","credit":{"html":"Photo by Dan Seifert / The Verge","plaintext":"Photo by Dan Seifert / The Verge"},"caption":{"html":"<em>None of the iPhone 15 models sport a notch. Instead, they support the Dynamic Island.</em>","plaintext":"None of the iPhone 15 models sport a notch. Instead, they support the Dynamic Island."},"contentWarning":{"plaintext":""},"thumbnail":{"size":"original","url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916168/DSCF3256.JPG?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0,0,100,100","normalizedRatio":1.5,"originalHeight":2944,"originalWidth":4416,"cropCoordinates":{"height":100,"width":100}},"image":{"id":"dmcyOmltYWdlOjUxNzAz","alt":""}},{"__isBlockType":"CoreHeadingBlockType","__typename":"CoreHeadingBlockType","contents":{"html":"Display and design"},"headingId":"vhPPlU","level":2,"placement":"default"},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"Now let’s talk about the display. This year, Apple swapped out the notch found on the lower-end iPhone 14 and iPhone 14 Plus for the Dynamic Island. Once reserved only for the premium iPhone 14 models, the feature essentially acts as a moveable pill-shaped cutout, one that displays real-time notifications, alerts, and activities."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"RelatedPostsBlockType","__typename":"RelatedPostsBlockType","links":[{"url":"https://www.theverge.com/23864716/iphone-15-dynamic-island-live-activities-wonderlust","title":"Dynamic Island isn’t such an exciting destination after all — and that’s okay"},{"url":"https://www.theverge.com/2023/9/12/23870441/apple-usb-c-cables-lightning-dongle-price","title":"Apple’s new USB-C iPhone cables and dongles are predictably expensive"}],"placement":"default"},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"Speaking of changes to the display, every phone in the iPhone 15 lineup features a brighter screen than the iPhone 14, with a peak brightness of 2,000 nits. Theoretically, this means the display should be easier to view when you’re outside, though we’ll let you know how that pans out once we’ve tested it. In addition to the Dynamic Island, the iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max also feature an always-on display, which is something the entry-level iPhone 14 and 15 models lack."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"There are also some notable design differences to be aware of. Only the iPhone 15 and Pro Max feature a titanium body, for example, which should make the smartphones both stronger and lighter. They’re also the only Apple phones to feature the <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/9/12/23870156/iphone-15-pro-action-button-ring-silence">Action Button</a>, which essentially takes the place of the ringer button and can be customized to create shortcuts, launch the camera, and carry out a range of other tasks."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"CoreImageBlockType","__typename":"CoreImageBlockType","alt":"A picture of the USB-C port on the bottom of an iPhone 15","hideCredit":false,"placement":"wide","credit":{"html":"Photo by Dan Seifert / The Verge","plaintext":"Photo by Dan Seifert / The Verge"},"caption":{"html":"<em>The iPhone 15 Plus, like the other phones in Apple’s 2023 lineup, finally features a USB-C port.</em>","plaintext":"The iPhone 15 Plus, like the other phones in Apple’s 2023 lineup, finally features a USB-C port."},"contentWarning":{"plaintext":""},"thumbnail":{"size":"original","url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916142/DSCF3231.JPG?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0,0,100,100","normalizedRatio":1.5,"originalHeight":2944,"originalWidth":4416,"cropCoordinates":{"height":100,"width":100}},"image":{"id":"dmcyOmltYWdlOjUxNzEz","alt":"A picture of the USB-C port on the bottom of an iPhone 15"}},{"__isBlockType":"CoreHeadingBlockType","__typename":"CoreHeadingBlockType","contents":{"html":"Charging and battery life"},"headingId":"rGTR69","level":2,"placement":"default"},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"Unsurprisingly, USB-C is perhaps one of the more notable updates this year. Each phone in the iPhone 15 lineup now features a USB-C port on the bottom instead of Apple’s proprietary Lightning connector, which the iPhone 14 lineup is still stuck with. The long-rumored switch should allow for faster charging and higher data transfer rates, too, and is particularly true of the 15 Pro, which Apple says is the first phone to offer 10Gbps transfer speeds. That means it should be significantly faster at transferring large files, including photos and videos."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"In terms of battery life, both the iPhone 14 and iPhone 15 max out at 20 hours, while the iPhone 15 Pro Max should last the longest at up to 29 hours. Both Plus models offer up to 26 hours of video playback, but strangely, the iPhone 15 Pro maxes out at 23 hours."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"CoreImageBlockType","__typename":"CoreImageBlockType","alt":"iPhone Pro models on a bed of bouncy balls.","hideCredit":false,"placement":"wide","credit":{"html":"Photo by Amelia Holowaty Krales / The Verge","plaintext":"Photo by Amelia Holowaty Krales / The Verge"},"caption":{"html":"<em>Apple introduced larger 48MP main camera sensors in the iPhone 14 Pro Max last year, which are now available on every iPhone 15 model.</em>","plaintext":"Apple introduced larger 48MP main camera sensors in the iPhone 14 Pro Max last year, which are now available on every iPhone 15 model."},"contentWarning":{"plaintext":""},"thumbnail":{"size":"original","url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24020041/226270_iPHONE_14_PHO_akrales_0724.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0,0,100,100","normalizedRatio":1.5,"originalHeight":1360,"originalWidth":2040,"cropCoordinates":{"height":100,"width":100}},"image":{"id":"dmcyOmltYWdlOjUxNzIy","alt":"iPhone Pro models on a bed of bouncy balls."}},{"__isBlockType":"CoreHeadingBlockType","__typename":"CoreHeadingBlockType","contents":{"html":"Cameras"},"headingId":"GftcJK","level":2,"placement":"default"},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"When it comes to cameras, the entry-level iPhone 14 and iPhone 15 models share a dual-camera system that includes a 12-megapixel ultrawide camera. This year, however, the iPhone 15 and 15 Plus offer an improved 48-megapixel main shooter — more specifically, the same high-resolution main camera found in the Pro models. In contrast, the iPhone 14 offers a lower-resolution 12-megapixel main shooter. The new iPhone 15 lineup also brings some updates to both night mode and Portrait mode, the latter of which will now automatically go into effect when you’re taking photos of people or animals."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"All of the entry-level models lack the triple-camera array found in the premium iPhone 15 models, which includes an additional 12-megapixel telephoto lens. You can also now change the main camera lens in the Pro models and shoot at multiple focal lengths: 24mm, 28mm, and 35mm. The iPhone 15 Pro Max has a new 5x tetraprism zoom lens with a 120mm focal length, too, which is the most Apple has ever offered and longer than the 3X 77mm focal length on the iPhone 15 Pro."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"RelatedPostsBlockType","__typename":"RelatedPostsBlockType","links":[{"url":"https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/5/23750003/apple-vision-pro-hands-on-the-best-headset-demo-ever","title":"I wore the Apple Vision Pro. It’s the best headset demo ever."}],"placement":"default"},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"There are also notable improvements when it comes to video recording. All of the phones feature a cinematic mode that can record 4K resolution at 30fps and 4K at 24fps. However, the 15 Pro models will also be able to capture “spatial video” later this year, which are essentially 3D videos that can be viewed with <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/9/12/23860400/apple-vision-pro-mixed-reality-headset-release-date">Apple’s forthcoming Vision Pro headset</a>. They will also allow you to shoot 4K60 ProRes video and, thanks to their support for USB-C, let you record video to external storage devices."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"CoreImageBlockType","__typename":"CoreImageBlockType","alt":"A person using an Apple Vision Pro watches a video.","hideCredit":false,"placement":"wide","credit":{"html":"Image: Apple","plaintext":"Image: Apple"},"caption":{"html":"<em>You’ll be able to capture spatial videos later this year on the iPhone 15 Pro models, which you can then watch on the Apple Vision Pro.</em>","plaintext":"You’ll be able to capture spatial videos later this year on the iPhone 15 Pro models, which you can then watch on the Apple Vision Pro."},"contentWarning":{"plaintext":""},"thumbnail":{"size":"original","url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916539/apple_spatial_video_vision_pro.png?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0,0,100,100","normalizedRatio":1.777778,"originalHeight":1440,"originalWidth":2560,"cropCoordinates":{"height":100,"width":100}},"image":{"id":"dmcyOmltYWdlOjUxNzM2","alt":"A person using an Apple Vision Pro watches a video."}},{"__isBlockType":"CoreHeadingBlockType","__typename":"CoreHeadingBlockType","contents":{"html":"Processing power"},"headingId":"PshXks","level":2,"placement":"default"},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"In terms of performance, the iPhone 14 and iPhone 14 Plus use the two-year-old A15 Bionic chipset, which we found fast enough in our testing. However, it’s likely less snappy than the A16 found in the entry-level iPhone 15 models and probably more noticeably so when compared to the premium phones. The iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max run on the new A17 Pro chip, after all, which Apple claims to be some of the fastest chips currently available."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"Combined with an updated GPU, Apple says the new smartphones are particularly well-suited for demanding tasks, including gaming. The iPhone 15 Pro seems to handle games well enough, at least in our <a href="https://www.theverge.com/23859793/iphone-15-pro-max-hands-on-pictures-video-apple">brief time playing with it</a>, but we’ll have to test it more to know for sure."},"dropcap":false,"endmark":false,"lead":false},{"__isBlockType":"CoreParagraphBlockType","__typename":"CoreParagraphBlockType","contents":{"html":"Speaking of chips, the iPhone 15 comes with a second-gen ultra wideband chip like the new <a href="https://www.theverge.com/23862174/apple-watch-series-9-ultra-2-preorder-buy-price-release-date">Apple Watch Series 9</a>. That is always the question.","image":null},"promo":{"headline":"How the new iPhone 15 models differ from one another (and the iPhone 14)"},"ledeMedia":{"__typename":"LedeMediaImageType","image":{"title":"A hand holding up an iPhone 15 Pro model","alt":"A hand holding up an iPhone 15 Pro model","originalHeight":3712,"originalWidth":5568,"thumbnails":{"social":{"url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916310/DSC_1099.jpeg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0,10.732984293194,100,78.534031413613","mimeType":"imageJpg","normalizedRatio":1.91,"cropCoordinates":{"height":78.53403141361257,"width":100}},"horizontal":{"url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916310/DSC_1099.jpeg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0,0,100,100","cropCoordinates":{"height":100,"width":100}},"square":{"url":"https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916310/DSC_1099.jpeg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=16.666666666667,0,66.666666666667,100","cropCoordinates":{"height":100,"width":66.66666666666666}}},"id":"dmcyOmltYWdlOjMwNzMw"}},"updatedAt":null,"createdAt":"2023-09-13T18:49:41+00:00","additionalBylines":"","status":"publish","wordCount":1436,"package":null,"streams":{"nodes":[{"id":"dmcyOnN0cmVhbToyOTg1NQ==","chorusId":23649589},{"id":"dmcyOnN0cmVhbToxOTM5OQ==","chorusId":23626878}]},"internalSuperCats":[],"superCats":[],"liveStatus":{"startAt":null,"status":false,"endAt":null},"isPaywallEligible":true,"seoArticleBody":"To the surprise of no one, Apple announced the new iPhone 15 during its Wonderlust event on Tuesday, introducing it alongside the new Apple Watch Series 9 and an updated pair of AirPods Pro that come with a USB-C charging case. That means, as of today, Apple’s iPhone lineup consists of the iPhone 15, 15 Plus, 15 Pro, and 15 Pro Max, as well as the last-gen iPhone 14, iPhone 13, and the third-gen iPhone SE. The iPhone 15 lineup won’t be available until September 22nd, but you can preorder the phones on September 15th, starting at $799.
Every phone in the new iPhone 15 lineup comes with a USB-C port and does away with the notch in favor of Apple’s Dynamic Island feature. Meanwhile, the more premium phones — specifically the iPhone 15 Pro and 15 Pro Max — come equipped with the new A17 Pro chip, an Action Button, and 10Gbps transfer speeds.
This is all exciting stuff, but do these new improvements justify the price? To help you decide, we’ve put together a spec-by-spec breakdown of how the entry-level iPhone 14 models stack up against the entire iPhone 15 lineup ahead of our full reviews later this month.
[Video: iPhone 15 Pro Max: titanium, Action Button, and USB-C]
Price and size
Before we dive into the nitty-gritty details, we should probably address one of the more significant differences between the various models: the price. The 6.1-inch iPhone 14 has dropped to $699, while the iPhone 15 starts at $799. The iPhone 14 Plus and iPhone 15 Plus go for $799 and $899, respectively, both of which come with a larger 6.7-inch display.
The 6.1-inch iPhone 15 Pro, meanwhile, starts at $999, while the 6.7-inch iPhone 15 Pro Max starts at $1,199. Along with more capabilities (which we’ll dive into shortly), the Pro models offer a 1TB storage option, which the entry-level iPhone 14 and 15 models lack.
[Image: None of the iPhone 15 models sport a notch. Instead, they support the Dynamic Island. https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916168/DSCF3256.JPG?quality=90&strip=all]
Display and design
Now let’s talk about the display. This year, Apple swapped out the notch found on the lower-end iPhone 14 and iPhone 14 Plus for the Dynamic Island. Once reserved only for the premium iPhone 14 models, the feature essentially acts as a moveable pill-shaped cutout, one that displays real-time notifications, alerts, and activities.
Speaking of changes to the display, every phone in the iPhone 15 lineup features a brighter screen than the iPhone 14, with a peak brightness of 2,000 nits. Theoretically, this means the display should be easier to view when you’re outside, though we’ll let you know how that pans out once we’ve tested it. In addition to the Dynamic Island, the iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max also feature an always-on display, which is something the entry-level iPhone 14 and 15 models lack.
There are also some notable design differences to be aware of. Only the iPhone 15 and Pro Max feature a titanium body, for example, which should make the smartphones both stronger and lighter. They’re also the only Apple phones to feature the Action Button, which essentially takes the place of the ringer button and can be customized to create shortcuts, launch the camera, and carry out a range of other tasks.
[Image: The iPhone 15 Plus, like the other phones in Apple’s 2023 lineup, finally features a USB-C port. https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916142/DSCF3231.JPG?quality=90&strip=all]
Charging and battery life
Unsurprisingly, USB-C is perhaps one of the more notable updates this year. Each phone in the iPhone 15 lineup now features a USB-C port on the bottom instead of Apple’s proprietary Lightning connector, which the iPhone 14 lineup is still stuck with. The long-rumored switch should allow for faster charging and higher data transfer rates, too, and is particularly true of the 15 Pro, which Apple says is the first phone to offer 10Gbps transfer speeds. That means it should be significantly faster at transferring large files, including photos and videos.
In terms of battery life, both the iPhone 14 and iPhone 15 max out at 20 hours, while the iPhone 15 Pro Max should last the longest at up to 29 hours. Both Plus models offer up to 26 hours of video playback, but strangely, the iPhone 15 Pro maxes out at 23 hours.
[Image: Apple introduced larger 48MP main camera sensors in the iPhone 14 Pro Max last year, which are now available on every iPhone 15 model. https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24020041/226270_iPHONE_14_PHO_akrales_0724.jpg?quality=90&strip=all]
Cameras
When it comes to cameras, the entry-level iPhone 14 and iPhone 15 models share a dual-camera system that includes a 12-megapixel ultrawide camera. This year, however, the iPhone 15 and 15 Plus offer an improved 48-megapixel main shooter — more specifically, the same high-resolution main camera found in the Pro models. In contrast, the iPhone 14 offers a lower-resolution 12-megapixel main shooter. The new iPhone 15 lineup also brings some updates to both night mode and Portrait mode, the latter of which will now automatically go into effect when you’re taking photos of people or animals.
All of the entry-level models lack the triple-camera array found in the premium iPhone 15 models, which includes an additional 12-megapixel telephoto lens. You can also now change the main camera lens in the Pro models and shoot at multiple focal lengths: 24mm, 28mm, and 35mm. The iPhone 15 Pro Max has a new 5x tetraprism zoom lens with a 120mm focal length, too, which is the most Apple has ever offered and longer than the 3X 77mm focal length on the iPhone 15 Pro.
There are also notable improvements when it comes to video recording. All of the phones feature a cinematic mode that can record 4K resolution at 30fps and 4K at 24fps. However, the 15 Pro models will also be able to capture “spatial video” later this year, which are essentially 3D videos that can be viewed with Apple’s forthcoming Vision Pro headset. They will also allow you to shoot 4K60 ProRes video and, thanks to their support for USB-C, let you record video to external storage devices.
[Image: You’ll be able to capture spatial videos later this year on the iPhone 15 Pro models, which you can then watch on the Apple Vision Pro. https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24916539/apple_spatial_video_vision_pro.png?quality=90&strip=all]
Processing power
In terms of performance, the iPhone 14 and iPhone 14 Plus use the two-year-old A15 Bionic chipset, which we found fast enough in our testing. However, it’s likely less snappy than the A16 found in the entry-level iPhone 15 models and probably more noticeably so when compared to the premium phones. The iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max run on the new A17 Pro chip, after all, which Apple claims to be some of the fastest chips currently available.
Combined with an updated GPU, Apple says the new smartphones are particularly well-suited for demanding tasks, including gaming. The iPhone 15 Pro seems to handle games well enough, at least in our brief time playing with it, but we’ll have to test it more to know for sure.
Speaking of chips, the iPhone 15 comes with a second-gen ultra wideband chip like the new Apple Watch Series 9. The updated component enables more precise tracking when using Apple’s Find My network, thus making it easier to find friends and loved ones who are also using an iPhone 15. It also should improve connectivity to other devices with the same chip that are further away.
[Image: The new StandBy mode in iOS 17 turns your phone into something like a smart display when it’s charging. https://platform.theverge.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24703759/wwdc_2023_243.jpg?quality=90&strip=all]
Software
Finally, when it comes to software, the iPhone 15 lineup ships with iOS 17. So far, that seems like a minor update that brings fun little features like Live Voicemail, a new Journal app, and StandBy mode. The latter turns your screen into something akin to a smart display, one that remains visible while your phone is charging in landscape mode. It should be noted, however, that you’ll also be able to download iOS 17 on the iPhone 14 and 15 Plus when it launches on September 18th, so you’ll be able to play with these features no matter which phone you buy.
By the numbers
There are other smaller differences to be aware of. All of the phones also support 5G, but only the 15 Pro models feature Wi-Fi 6E support. That makes them more futureproof and allows for faster wireless performance. The premium phones also come with a Thread radio built in, which can be used to control Thread-enabled smart home devices.
That’s just a brief overview of some of the main differences between the iPhone 15 and iPhone 14 lineup, though. You can dig into the more granular differences in the chart below, where we’ve rounded up all the relevant specs.

  --font: var(--font-polysans);

  --cta-font-weight: 500;
  
  --footer-top-bar-background-color: ;
  --footer-top-bar-text-color: ;
  --footer-top-bar-text-size: ;
  --footer-top-bar-height: ;

  --footer-top-bar-horizontal-alignment: center;
  --footer-top-bar-vertical-alignment: center;

  --body-background-color: #3CFFD0;
  --body-height: 0;

  --body-button-background-color: ;
  --body-button-background-hover-color: #000000;
  --body-button-text-color: #5200FF;
  --body-button-text-hover-color: #ffffff;
  --body-button-border-width: 1px;
  --body-button-border-radius: 2px;
  
  --subheading-text-max-width: ;

.zephr-svg-close {
    height: 24px;
    opacity: .5;
}

.zephr-svg-close:hover {
    opacity: 1;
}

.zephr-zone-footer {
    bottom: -100vh;
    z-index: 100000;
}

.zephr-zone-footer.transform {
    transition: translate .3s;
    translate: 0 -100vh;
}

#zephr-overlay {
    z-index: 99999;
    opacity: 1;
    transition: opacity .5s;
}

#zephr-footer-container {
  box-shadow: 0 0 5px rgba(0,0,0,.15);
  background-color: var(--body-background-color);
  min-height: var(--body-height);
  color: var(--body-text-color);
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
  font-family: var(--font); 
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
}

#zephr-footer-body {
  background-color: var(--body-background-color);
  min-height: var(--body-height);
  max-width: 1140px;
  color: var(--body-text-color);
  display: flex;
  padding: 24px;
  margin: auto;
  flex-direction: column;
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
  border: var(--border);
}


#zephr-footer-body button {
  background-color: var(--body-button-background-color);

  padding: 13px 24px;
  line-height: 20px;
  font-size: 12px;
  font-weight: var(--cta-font-weight);
  font-family: var(--cta-font);
  letter-spacing: 1.44px;
  white-space: nowrap;
  transition: color .2s, background-color .2s;
}

#zephr-footer-body button:hover {

  color: var(--body-button-text-hover-color);
}
